userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The materials from Washington and Lee University Special Collections are made available for use in research, teaching, and private study, pursuant to U.S. Copyright law. The user assumes full responsibility for any use of the materials, including but not limited to, infringement of copyright and publication rights of reproduced materials. Any materials used should be fully credited with the source. Permission for publication of this material, in part or in full, must be secured with the Head of Special Collections.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p:
Preferred citation: [Identification of item], John F. Swayne Papers, WLU Coll. 0292, Special Collections and Archives, James G. Leyburn Library, Washington and Lee University, Lexington, VA.
In some cases the citation format may vary. Please contact Special Collections staff to verify the appropriate format.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Several items in this collection were a gift of Mrs. Herbert E. Williams.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Blue sheet prepared by Lisa McCown (4/11/89).

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Swayne was a member of the Washington and Lee University Class of 1871, but he left the college by his own volition in 1869.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection consists of Swayne's personal papers from his time as a student at Washington College, including correspondence with E. C. Gordon and Mary F. Dickson, a subscription to the Southern Collegian, and two essays. One letter is a response from the clerk of the faculty to Swayne's notice of withdrawal from the college. One essay entitled 'A trip to House Mountain' was written in 1869; it details a trip made there in the summer of 1867. There is an accompanying note. The other essay is about Alexander the Great. There is also a 1935 newspaper article about his reminisces of his time at Washington College while Robert E. Lee was the university's president.
